3.09.text:
It's great to welcome President Obama again,
on his fifth visit to the United Kingdom.

8.62.text:
Barack has been President for more than seven
years; I've been Prime Minister for nearly

14.63.text:
And our two countries have been working together
through some of the most difficult and troubled

20.82.text:
We faced the aftermath of the banking crisis,
the need to revive growth and create jobs

25.51.text:
in our economies, new threats to our security
from Russia in the east to the rise of Islamist

31.13.text:
terrorists in the south, and, of course, huge
global challenges like Ebola and climate change.

37.15.text:
And through it all, the strong and essential
partnership between our nations has never

42.91.text:
When, 70 years ago last month, Winston Churchill
first described the special relationship,

49.35.text:
it was not merely and enduring expression
of friendship, it was a way of working together.

55.05.text:
It was about two nations, kindred spirits
who share the same values and, so often, the

60.17.text:
same approaches to the many issues that we
face.

63.92.text:
And just as for our predecessors, that has
been true for Barack and me, whether we're

68.32.text:
working to deliver economic security, national
security, or new, emerging challenges.

74.96.text: And today, we've been discussing all three.

77.74.text:
On economic security, we've succeeded in getting
our economies growing and creating jobs for

83.89.text:
The global economy still faces serious challenges,
but last year, Britain and the United States

89.21.text:
were the two fastest-growing major economies
in the world.

93.43.text:
And we both know just how important trade
deals are in driving global growth.

97.77.text:
So Barack and I remain among the most determined
to achieve our vision of a U.S.-EU trade deal.

104.27.text:
And we're working hard to push this forward
because it would add billions to our economies

108.87.text:
and set the standards for the rest of the
world to follow.

112.29.text:
On national security, together with our partners
in the EU, we've used our economic muscle

117.71.text:
to avoid the calamity of an Iranian nuclear
weapon.

121.33.text:
We've delivered sanctions against Russia in
response to its aggression against Ukraine.

126.43.text:
We've secured the first-ever global and legally
binding deal on climate change, being formally

131.63.text:
signed today by over 150 governments at the
United Nations.

136.44.text:
And we've transformed the way that we use
our aid, our diplomacy and our military together

141.49.text:
to make progress on some of the most difficult
issues of our time.

144.33.text:
For example, in East Africa, we’ve helped
to turn around the prospects for Somalia.

149.47.text:
For instance, thanks to an EU operation, led
by Britain, supported by America, its waters

155.39.text: are no longer a safe haven for pirates.

158.40.text:
And in West Africa, British leadership in
Europe secured a billion euros to support

162.84.text:
our efforts in helping the people of the region
to defeat the outbreak of Ebola, with Britain

168.12.text:
taking the lead in Sierra Leone, the United
States in Liberia, France in Guinea.

173.69.text:
But just as we've made important progress
in all these areas, so there are many more

178.12.text: that need a lot more work.

179.87.text:
There’s no doubt that the situation in Libya
is immensely challenging, but we now finally

184.88.text:
have a Government of National Accord with
whom we can work.

187.98.text:
While in Syria and Iraq, we are continuing
coalition efforts to defeat and degrade Daesch.

193.26.text:
More than 25,000 Daesch fighters have now
been killed, over 600 in the last month alone.

200.37.text:
With the total number of Daesch fighters,
they’re estimated to be at its lowest for

206.44.text:
The Iraqi security forces are steadily pushing
Daesch out of its territory, this week almost

212.15.text:
entirely clearing them out of the town of
Hit.

215.57.text:
And in Syria, our partners have liberated
the last Kurdish areas in the northeast and

220.37.text: cut off the main route between Raqqa and Mosul.

223.96.text:
We also discussed efforts to deal with the
migration crisis.

226.65.text:
This doesn’t directly affect the United
States, and in the UK, we've maintained our

232.01.text: borders and we will continue to do so.

234.74.text:
But we both know the challenge this poses
to our friends and our allies, and to the

240.62.text:
This is the sort of challenge that can only
be tackled effectively through international

246.21.text:
NATO is helping to reduce the number of migrants
in the Eastern Mediterranean.

250.68.text:
And Barack and I have discussed how NATO might
now contribute to the EU’s efforts in the

257.48.text:
We also need to do more to break the business
model of the people smugglers, so, together

261.75.text:
with our EU partners and the Libyan government,
we'll look at whether there’s more we can

265.74.text: do to strength the Libyan Coast Guard.

268.55.text:
Barack and I will be discussing this further
when we meet with the leaders of France, Germany

272.40.text: and Italy in Hannover on Monday.

274.97.text:
And this will be another opportunity to show
how, working together, collectively, we can

279.66.text:
better protect ourselves from the threats
that we face.

283.68.text:
We also covered a number of new and emerging
challenges where it will be more important

287.14.text:
than ever that we work together with our international
partners to identify problems and deal with

293.86.text:
Just as we've done with Ebola, we now need
the same international cooperation on dealing

298.39.text:
with the Zika virus, on the challenge of antimicrobial
resistance, on cybersecurity and on tackling

306.55.text:
Britain is holding a big anticorruption summit
here in London next month, which Secretary

312.59.text:
And Barack and I have talked today about some
of the things we wanted to achieve.

316.10.text:
One of the biggest problems is that if you're
a country that wants to take action against

319.43.text:
corruption you have to go all around the globe
to lobby for help.

322.90.text:
So we’d like to see an international anticorruption
coordination center to help law enforcement

328.10.text:
agencies and investigators work together right
across different jurisdictions.

332.24.text:
And if we get international agreement on this
next month, both Britain and America will

337.15.text: help contribute to set it up.

340.13.text:
All this work we have done together, and at
the same time, I think we've got to know each

346.03.text: I'm honored to have Barack as a friend.

347.99.text: He’s taught me the rules of basketball.

349.90.text: He’s beaten me at table tennis.

352.39.text:
I remember very fondly the barbecue we had
in Number 10 Downing Street, serving servicemen

358.49.text:
and women who serve our countries together
here in the United Kingdom.

363.82.text:
I've always found Barack someone who gives
sage advice.

368.24.text:
He’s a man with a very good heart, and been
a very good friend, and always will be a good

373.35.text: friend, I know, to the United Kingdom.

375.53.text: Let me finish by saying this.

378.65.text:
In all the areas we discussed today our collective
power and reach is amplified by Britain’s

387.44.text:
When it comes to the special relationship
between our two countries, there’s no greater

393.53.text:
I'm very proud to have the opportunity to
be Prime Minister and to stand outside the

398.13.text:
White House, listening to this man, my friend,
Barack, say that the special relationship

403.14.text: between our countries has never been stronger.

405.32.text:
But I've never felt constrained in any way
in strengthening this relationship by the

410.81.text: fact that we're in the European Union.

415.68.text:
We deliver for our people through all the
international groups that we're part of.

419.98.text:
We enhance our security through the membership
of NATO.

423.23.text:
We further our prosperity through the G7 and
the G20.

427.42.text:
And like those organizations, Britain’s
membership of the EU gives us a powerful tool

432.09.text:
to deliver on the prosperity and security
that our people need, and to stand up for

437.73.text: the values that our countries share.

440.66.text:
And now I think is a time to stay true to
those values and to stick together with our

446.02.text:
friends and allies in Europe and around the
world.

454.10.text:
And as always, it is wonderful to be here
in London, and to meet with my good friend,

460.23.text:
I confess I've also come back to wish Her
Majesty the Queen a very happy 90th birthday.

466.79.text:
Earlier today, Michelle and I had the honor
to join Her Majesty and His Royal Highness

473.63.text:
the Duke of Edinburgh as their guests at Windsor
Castle, where we conveyed the good wishes

480.94.text:
I have to say I have never been driven by
a Duke of Edinburgh before.

488.72.text: And I can report that it was very smooth riding.

495.11.text:
As for Her Majesty, the Queen has been a source
of inspiration for me, like so many people

502.31.text: She is truly one of my favorite people.

505.55.text:
And should we be fortunate enough to reach
90, may we be as vibrant as she is.

512.87.text:
She’s an astonishing person, and a real
jewel to the world and not just to the United

524.65.text:
The alliance between the United States and
the United Kingdom is one of the oldest and

530.47.text:
one of the strongest that the world has ever
known.

534.14.text:
When the U.S. and the UK stand together, we
make our countries more secure, we make our

538.87.text:
people more prosperous, and we make the world
safer and better.

545.56.text:
That’s one of the reasons why my first overseas
visit as President more than seven years ago

551.69.text: was here to London, at a time of global crisis.

557.88.text:
And the one thing I knew, as green as I was
as a new President, was that it was absolutely

564.40.text:
vital that the United States and the United
Kingdom, working together in an international

571.08.text: forum, tackle the challenges that lie ahead.

574.90.text:
Our success depended on our ability to coordinate
and to be able to leverage our relationship

582.18.text: to have an impact on other countries.

585.45.text: I met with David on that visit.

590.39.text:
But just as our nations share a special relationship,
David and I have shared an extraordinary partnership.

596.49.text:
He has proven to be a great friend, and is
one of my closest and most trusted partners.

602.44.text:
Over the six years or so that our terms have
overlapped, we have met or spoken more times

611.02.text:
We’ve shared our countries’ beers with
each other -- he vouches for his, I vouch

616.45.text:
for mine -- (laughter) -- taken in a basketball
game in America.

621.70.text:
David I think you should recall, we were actually
partners in that ping-pong game.

627.39.text: And we lost to some school children.

631.88.text:
I can’t remember whether they were eight
or 10, but they were decidedly shorter than

636.39.text: we were, and they whooped us.

641.35.text:
Samantha and Michelle, our better halves,
have become good friends as well.

644.22.text:
And it’s the depth and the breadth of that
special relationship that has helped us tackle

649.89.text:
some of the most daunting challenges of our
time.

653.80.text:
Around the world, our joint efforts, as David
mentioned, have stopped the outbreak of Ebola,

658.79.text:
kept Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon,
forged a climate agreement in Paris that hopefully

665.39.text:
will help to protect our planet for future
generations.

670.44.text:
And today, on Earth Day, our governments,
along with about 170 others, are in New York

677.54.text:
The U.S. is committed to formally joining
it this year, which should help it take effect

688.63.text:
We also discussed the full array of challenges
to our shared security.

693.08.text:
We remain resolute in our efforts to prevent
terrorist attacks against our people, and

698.01.text:
to continue the progress that we’ve made
in rolling back and ultimately defeating ISIL.

702.72.text:
Our forces, as David mentioned, are systematically
degrading ISIL’s finances and safe havens,

709.44.text: and removing its top leaders from the battlefield.

711.89.text:
We’ve got to keep working to improve security
and information-sharing across Europe, and

716.65.text:
to stem the flow of foreign fighters into
and out of Syria.

721.34.text:
We discussed our efforts to resolve political
conflicts in the Middle East, from Yemen to

725.39.text:
Syria to Libya, in order to increase the prospects
for stability.

730.04.text:
In Libya, going forward, we have an opportunity
to support a new government and help Libyans

737.89.text:
In Syria, as challenging as it is, we still
need to see more progress towards an enduring

744.73.text:
ceasefire, and we continue to push for greater

750.93.text:
We have to continue to invest in NATO so that

757.49.text:
We have to resolve the conflict in the Ukraine

765.03.text:
All NATO allies should aim for the NATO target
of spending 2 percent of their GDP on defense

771.08.text:
-- something that David has made sure happens
here in the UK to meet that standard.

777.84.text:
We discussed new actions we can take to address
the refugee crisis, including with our NATO

783.48.text:
And because a strong defense relies on more
than just military spending but on helping

788.94.text:
to unleash the potential of others to live
freer and more prosperous lives, I want to

793.69.text:
thank the people of the United Kingdom for
their extraordinary generosity as one of the

797.37.text: world's foremost donors of humanitarian aid.

801.23.text:
We talked about promoting jobs and stronger
growth through increased transatlantic trade

806.20.text:
and investment so that our young people can
achieve greater opportunity and prosperity.

810.47.text:
And, yes, the Prime Minister and I discussed
the upcoming referendum here on whether or

816.39.text:
not the UK should remain part of the European
Union.

822.11.text:
Ultimately, this is something that the British
voters have to decide for themselves.

828.43.text:
But as part of our special relationship, part
of being friends is to be honest and to let

840.23.text:
And speaking honestly, the outcome of that

845.26.text:
United States because it affects our prospects

848.89.text:
The United States wants a strong United Kingdom
as a partner.

853.65.text:
And the United Kingdom is at its best when
it's helping to lead a strong Europe.

860.42.text:
It leverages UK power to be part of the European
Union.

867.53.text:
As I wrote in the op-ed here today, I don't
believe the EU moderates British influence

873.40.text: in the world -- it magnifies it.

876.26.text:
The EU has helped to spread British values
and practices across the continent.

880.67.text:
The single market brings extraordinary economic
benefits to the United Kingdom.

886.40.text:
And that ends up being good for America, because
we're more prosperous when one of our best

891.79.text:
friends and closest allies has a strong, stable,
growing economy.

898.02.text:
Americans want Britain's influence to grow,
including within Europe.

905.37.text:
The fact is, in today's world no nation is
immune to the challenges that David and I

911.85.text:
And in today's world, solving them requires

916.78.text:
All of us cherish our sovereignty -- my country
is pretty vocal about that -- but the U.S.

922.73.text:
also recognizes that we strengthen our security
through our membership in NATO.

927.15.text:
We strengthen our prosperity through organizations
like the G7 and the G20.

932.15.text:
And I believe the UK strengthens both our
collective security and prosperity through

937.71.text:
In the 21st century, the nations that make
their presence felt on the world stage aren't

944.49.text:
the nations that go it alone but the nations
that team up to aggregate their power and

952.76.text:
And precisely because Britain's values and

961.37.text:
want to make sure that that influence is heard,

975.50.text:
We have confidence that when the UK is involved
in a problem that they're going to help solve

986.85.text: That's why the United States cares about this.

991.56.text:
For centuries, Europe was marked by war and
by violence.

997.13.text:
The architecture that our two countries helped
build with the EU has provided the foundation

1003.00.text:
for decades of relative peace and prosperity
on that continent.

1009.18.text:
What a remarkable legacy -- a legacy born
in part out of what took place in this building.

1019.11.text:
Before we walked out, I happened to see Enigma
on display.

1026.68.text:
And that was a reminder of the incredible
innovation and collaboration of the allies

1035.00.text:
in World War II and the fact that neither
of us could have won that alone.

1042.54.text:
And in the same way, after World War II, we

1050.18.text:
yes, occasionally constrained us, but we willingly

1058.44.text:
that by doing so, we were able to institutionalize

1066.14.text:
of law, and freedom, and democracy, that would
benefit our citizens as well as people around

1082.50.text:
I think there's a British poet who once said,
"No man is an island" -- even an island as

1093.86.text:
And if we continue to tackle our challenges
together, then future generations will look

1098.66.text:
back on ours, just as we look back on the

1109.50.text:
citizens who worked so hard to make this world
safer and more secure and more prosperous,

1115.90.text: and they'll say that we did our part, too.

1120.81.text:
That's important not just here; that's important
in the United States, as well.

1126.49.text: PRIME MINISTER CAMERON: Thank you very much.

1127.94.text: All right, we've got some questions.

We're going to start with a question from
the British press.

1132.16.text: We'll have Chris Ship from ITV.

1134.04.text: Q Thank you very much, Prime Minister.

1141.04.text:
Mr. President, you, yourself, acknowledge

1147.11.text:
on the EU referendum and the spirited debate

1153.04.text:

1159.09.text:
America would not accept the loss of sovereignty
that we have to accept as part of the EU.

1165.22.text:
America would not accept the levels of immigration
from Mexico that we have to accept from the

1172.03.text:
And therefore, in various degrees of politeness,
they have said to you that you should really

1178.63.text:
With that in mind, Mr. President, do you still

1186.16.text:
And can I ask you this -- truthfully, what
happens if the UK does decide in June to leave

1192.25.text:
PRESIDENT OBAMA: Well, firsts of all, let
me repeat, this is a decision for the people

1199.06.text: of the United Kingdom to make.

1201.34.text: I’m not coming here to fix any votes.

1204.59.text: I’m not casting a vote myself.

1212.17.text:
And in democracies, everybody should want
more information, not less.

1217.28.text:
And you shouldn’t be afraid to hear an argument
being made.

1230.75.text:
Particularly because my understanding is that
some of the folks on the other side have been

1235.28.text:

1243.90.text:
So they say, for example, that, well, we’ll
just cut our own trade deals with the United

1250.44.text:
So they're voicing an opinion about what the

1254.29.text:
I figured you might want to hear it from the
President of the United States what I think

1257.79.text: the United States is going to do.

1261.54.text:
And on that matter, for example, I think it’s
fair to say that maybe some point down the

1268.16.text:
line, there might be a UK-U.S. trade agreement,
but it’s not going to happen anytime soon,

1273.29.text:
because our focus is in negotiating with a
big bloc, the European Union, to get a trade

1278.72.text:
agreement done, and the UK is going to be
in the back of the queue -- not because we

1285.52.text:
don't have a special relationship, but because,
given the heavy lift on any trade agreement,

1293.92.text:
us having access to a big market with a lot
of countries -- rather than trying to do piecemeal

1307.39.text:
Now, to the subject at hand, obviously the
United States is in a different hemisphere,

1320.96.text:
different circumstances, has different sets
of relationships with its neighbors than the

1327.34.text: But I can tell you this.

1329.87.text:
If, right now, I’ve got access to a massive
market where I sell 44 percent of my exports,

1343.22.text:
and now I’m thinking about leaving the organization
that gives me access to that market and that

1351.10.text:
is responsible for millions of jobs in my
country and responsible for an enormous amount

1360.08.text:
of commerce and upon which a lot of businesses
depend, that's not something I’d probably

1373.41.text:
And what I’m trying to describe is a broader
principle, which is, in our own ways -- I

1382.79.text:
mean, we don't have a common market in the
Americas -- but in all sorts of ways, the

1391.97.text:
United States constrains itself in order to
bind everyone under a common set of norms

1401.52.text: and rules that makes everybody more prosperous.

1407.46.text: That's what we built after World War II.

1409.80.text:
The United States and the UK designed a set
of institutions -- whether it was the United

1418.95.text:
Nations, or the Bretton Woods structure, IMF,
World Bank, NATO, across the board.

1428.34.text:
Now, that, to some degree, constrained our
freedom to operate.

1434.96.text:
It meant that occasionally we had to deal
with some bureaucracy.

1439.00.text:
It meant that on occasion we have to persuade
other countries, and we don't get 100 percent

1446.91.text: of what we want in each case.

1449.75.text:
But we knew that by doing so, everybody was
going to be better off -- partly because the

1455.96.text:
norms and rules that were put in place were
reflective of what we believe.

1465.40.text:
If there were more free markets around the
world, and an orderly financial system, we

1471.47.text: knew we could operate in that environment.

1475.89.text:
If we had collective defense treaties through
NATO, we understood that we could formalize

1484.73.text:
an architecture that would deter aggression,
rather than us having, piecemeal, to put together

1492.97.text:
alliances to defeat aggression after it already
started.

1499.80.text: And that principle is what’s at stake here.

1502.18.text:
And the last point I’ll make on this -- until
I get the next question, I suspect -- (laughter)

1508.62.text:
-- is that, as David said, this magnifies
the power of the UK.

1524.70.text:
On just about every issue, what happens in
Europe is going to have an impact here.

1530.78.text:
And what happens in Europe is going to have
an impact in the United States.

1533.97.text:
We just discussed, for example, the refugee
and the migration crisis.

1537.54.text:
And I’ve told my team -- which is sitting
right here, so they’ll vouch for me -- that

1543.92.text:
we consider it a major national security issue
that you have uncontrolled migration into

1549.41.text:
Europe -- not because these folks are coming
to the United States, but because if it destabilizes

1558.58.text:
Europe, our largest trading bloc -- trading
partner -- it’s going to be bad for our

1568.59.text:
If you start seeing divisions in Europe, that
weakens NATO.

1576.10.text:
That will have an impact on our collective
security.

1579.42.text:
Now, if, in fact, I want somebody who’s
smart and common sense, and tough, and is

1590.57.text:
thinking, as I do, in the conversations about
how migration is going to be handled, somebody

1596.86.text:
who also has a sense of compassion, and recognizes
that immigration can enhance, when done properly,

1605.47.text:
the assets of a country, and not just diminish
them, I want David Cameron in the conversation.

1613.45.text:
Just as I want him in the conversation when
we're having discussions about information-sharing

1622.54.text:
Precisely because I have confidence in the
UK, and I know that if we're not working effectively

1633.27.text:
with Paris or Brussels, then those attacks
are going to migrate to the United States

1637.73.text:
and to London, I want one of my strongest
partners in that conversation.

1645.17.text: So it enhances the special relationship.

1648.06.text:
PRIME MINISTER CAMERON: Let me just make,
Chris, one point in response to that.

1653.45.text:
This is our choice; nobody else’s -- the
sovereign choice of the British people.

1658.43.text:
But as we make that choice, it surely makes
sense to listen to what our friends think,

1663.29.text:
to listen to their opinion, to listen to their
views.

1665.55.text:
And that's what Barack has been talking about
today.

1668.44.text:
But it’s also worth remembering as we make
this choice, it’s a British choice about

1673.72.text: the British membership of the European Union.

1676.57.text:
We're not being asked to make a choice about
whether we support the German style of membership,

1682.06.text: or the Italian style of membership.

1684.23.text:
Britain has a special status in the European
Union.

1687.50.text:
We're in the single market; we're not part
of the single currency.

1690.82.text:
We're able to travel and live and work in
other European countries, but we’ve maintained

1696.53.text:
our borders, because we’re not in the Schengen
no-border zone.

1700.67.text:
And on this vital issue of trade, where Barack
has made such a clear statement, we should

1706.67.text:
remember why we are currently negotiating
this biggest trade deal in the whole world,

1713.08.text:
and in the whole world’s history, between

1717.45.text:
because Britain played an absolutely leading

1729.31.text:
We set the agenda for what could be an absolutely

1795.43.text: PRESIDENT OBAMA: That was so predictable.

1804.38.text:
PRESIDENT OBAMA: I wouldn’t describe European

1815.26.text:

1844.78.text:
But we’ve seen some divisions and difficulties

1866.00.text:
At a time of globalization, at a time when

1877.41.text:
as opposed to just focused on one country,
there is a temptation to want to just pull

1885.85.text: up the drawbridge, either literally or figuratively.

1898.28.text:
And that debate I think is accelerated in

1906.67.text:
But I’m confident that the ties that bind

1915.36.text:
than the forces that are trying to pull them

1920.47.text:
Europe has undergone an extraordinary stretch
of prosperity -- maybe unmatched in the history

1933.45.text:
If you think about the 20th century and you
think about the 21st century, 21st century

1939.92.text: Europe looks an awful lot better.

1942.96.text:
And I think the majority of Europeans recognize
that.

1947.16.text:
They see that unity and peace have delivered
sustained economic growth, reduced conflict,

1958.48.text:
reduced violence, enhanced the quality of
life for people.

1964.45.text: And I’m confident that can continue.

1966.84.text:
But I do believe that it’s important to
watch out for some of these fault lines that

1975.37.text:
And in that sense, I do think that the Brexit

1983.89.text:
thinking about it solely in terms of how is

1989.67.text:

1998.34.text:
But I do also think that this vote will send

2005.09.text:
kind of prosperity that we’ve built together

2013.10.text: of division end up being more prominent.

2017.05.text:
And that’s why it’s -- that’s part of
the reason why it’s relevant to the United

2021.38.text:
States, and why I have had the temerity to

2030.06.text: What were your four other questions?

2033.18.text:
I've got to figure I've knocked out two through

2037.03.text:
PRESIDENT OBAMA: With respect to Libya, both
David and I discussed our commitment to try

2048.41.text:
And it's a challenge, but there are people

2070.61.text:

2077.48.text:

2088.90.text:

2094.25.text:
They're actually much better-positioned than

2135.89.text:
But I do think that the one area where both

And so we are working not just with the Libyan

2174.80.text:
And I think you have to wait until I get to

2180.62.text:
PRIME MINISTER CAMERON: The question you asked

And as Barack has explained, it's a referendum

2192.32.text:

2199.52.text:
partners like America, or Canada, or Australia,

2203.22.text:
And as I look around the world, it is hard

2209.75.text:
country that wishes Britain well that thinks

2216.16.text: And I think that's -- again, it's our choice.

2220.19.text: We'll listen to all the arguments.

2223.85.text: They want to know the consequences.

2224.94.text:
And I'll try to lay those out as Prime Minister
as clearly as I can.

2229.15.text:
But listening to our friends, listening to
countries that wish us well, is part of the

2233.87.text: process and is a good thing to do.

2236.21.text:
As for the American elections, I've made some
comments in recent weeks and months.

2242.47.text:
I don't think now is a moment to add to add

2247.65.text:
But I think, just as a Prime Minister who’s
been through two general elections leading

2253.19.text:
my party, you always look on at the U.S. elections
in awe of the scale of the process and the

2258.73.text:
length of the process, and I marvel at anyone
who is left standing at the end of it.

2267.45.text: So I, too, can look in awe at the process.

2275.20.text:

2388.27.text:

2396.71.text:
against aggression, how can it be an interest

2415.81.text:
I would just say about the special relationship,

2423.60.text:
and the culture, but also about the future

2428.73.text:
stronger Britain is, and the stronger America

2434.25.text: And I want Britain to be as strong as possible.

2437.97.text:
And we draw our strength from all sorts of

2441.56.text:
largest economy in the world; amazing armed

2445.82.text:

2450.65.text:

2456.90.text:
But we also draw strength, and project strength,

2461.73.text:
and protect our people, and make our country
wealthier, our people wealthier by being in

2468.29.text: So I want Britain to be as strong as possible.

2470.96.text:
And the stronger Britain is, the stronger
that special relationship is, and the more

2474.66.text:
that we can get done together to make sure
that we have a world that promotes democracy

2478.78.text:
and peace and human rights and the development

So, to me, it’s simple: Stronger Britain,

2487.57.text:

2493.53.text:
PRESIDENT OBAMA: Let me start with Winston

2698.42.text:
We are so bound together that nothing is going

So I don’t come here, suggesting in any

But, as David said, if one of our best friends

Or at least I want to be able to tell them,

But precisely because we’re bound at the
hip, I want you to know that before you make

2788.15.text: Q Thank you very much, sir.

2794.85.text:
Mr. President, Vladimir Putin hasn’t stopped
Assad, as he led you to believe he would,

2800.13.text:
and the ceasefire in Syria appears to be falling

2803.82.text:
Will you continue to bet on what looks to

2809.51.text:
Mr. Prime Minister, the UK today warned its
citizens traveling to North Carolina and Mississippi

2815.11.text: about laws there that affect transgender individuals.

2819.45.text: As a friend, what do you think of those laws?

2822.45.text:
Mr. President, would you like to weigh in
on that?

2824.29.text: And, sir, if you’d indulge us --

2826.36.text: PRESIDENT OBAMA: Indulge -- what do you mean?

2829.06.text:
Q Well, indulge all of us back in the U.S.,
sir, Prince passed away.

2836.41.text:
You had invited him to perform at the White
House.

2838.20.text: Can you tell us what made you a fan?

2842.12.text:
PRESIDENT OBAMA: I’m trying to figure out
which order to do this.

2850.04.text:
Maybe I’ll start with North Carolina and
Mississippi.

2855.40.text:
I want everybody here in the United Kingdom
to know that the people of North Carolina

2863.86.text:
They are beautiful states, and you are welcome
and you should come and enjoy yourselves.

2870.30.text:
And I think you’ll be treated with extraordinary
hospitality.

2873.17.text:
I also think that the laws that have been
passed there are wrong and should be overturned.

2881.39.text:
And they’re in response to politics, in
part; in part, some strong emotions that are

2891.86.text:
generated by people -- some of whom are good
people but I just disagree with when it comes

2900.89.text:
to respecting the equal rights of all people,
regardless of sexual orientation, whether

2907.97.text: they're transgender or gay or lesbian.

2913.02.text:
And although I respect their different viewpoints,
I think it’s very important for us not to

2919.00.text: send signals that anybody is treated differently.

2923.53.text:
And I think it’s fair to say that we're
not unique among countries where -- particularly

2928.34.text:
under a federal system in which power is dispersed,
that there are going to be some localities

2935.14.text:
or local officials that put forward laws that
aren’t necessarily reflective of a national

2943.96.text:
But if you guys come to North Carolina or
Mississippi, everybody will be treated well.

2950.22.text: The second question with respect to Syria.

2952.16.text:
I am deeply concerned about the cessation
of hostilities fraying and whether it’s

2961.56.text:
Now, keep in mind that I have always been
skeptical about Mr. Putin’s actions and

2971.96.text:
He is -- along with Iran -- the preeminent
backer of a murderous regime that I do not

2979.38.text:
believe can regain legitimacy within his country
because he’s murdered a lot of people.

2990.39.text:
Having said that, what I also believe is,
is that we cannot end the crisis in Syria

2999.86.text:
without political negotiations and without
getting all the parties around the table to

3009.58.text:
And that, by necessity, means that there are
going to be some people on one side of the

3014.36.text:
table who I deeply disagree with and whose
actions I deeply abhor.

3024.55.text:
That's how oftentimes you resolve conflicts
like this that are taking an enormous toll

3033.76.text:
The cessation of hostilities actually held
longer than I expected.

3040.21.text:
And for seven weeks we've seen a significant
reduction in violence inside that country.

3048.75.text: And that gave some relief to people.

3051.18.text:
I talked to Putin on Monday precisely to reinforce
to him the importance of us trying to maintain

3059.57.text:
the cessation of hostilities, asking him to
put more pressure on Assad, indicating to

3066.48.text:
him that we would continue to try to get the
moderate opposition to stay at the negotiating

3076.21.text: But this has always been hard.

3078.60.text: And it’s going to keep being hard.

3080.73.text:
And what David and I discussed in our meeting
was that we will continue to prosecute the

3091.16.text:
We are going to continue to support those
who are prepared to fight ISIL.

3094.94.text: And we're going to continue to target them.

3097.09.text: We're going to continue to make progress.

3099.49.text:
But we're not going to solve the overall problem
unless we can get this political track moving.

3106.61.text: I assure you that we have looked at all options.

3113.08.text: And so we are going to play this option out.

3115.77.text:
If, in fact, the cessation falls apart, we’ll
try to put it back together again even as

3121.21.text: we continue to go after ISIL.

3125.44.text:
And it’s my belief that ultimately Russia
will recognize that, just as this can't be

3136.20.text:
solved by a military victory on the part of
those we support, Russia may be able to keep

3146.35.text:
the lid on, alongside Iran, for a while, but
if you don't have a legitimate government

3152.99.text: there, they will be bled, as well.

3158.16.text:
And that is not -- that's not speculation
on my part.

3164.64.text: I think the evidence all points in that direction.

3169.72.text:
And finally with respect to Prince, I loved
Prince because he put out great music and

3180.92.text:
He came to perform at the White House last
year and was extraordinary, and creative and

3196.20.text: And so it’s a remarkable loss.

3199.47.text:
And I’m staying at Winfield House, the U.S.
Ambassador’s residence.

3202.65.text:
It so happens our Ambassador has a turntable,
and so this morning we played “Purple Rain”

3208.93.text:
and “Delirious” just to get warmed up
before we left the house for important bilateral

3218.13.text:
PRIME MINISTER CAMERSON: As a fan of great
music, the Ambassador has brought a lot of

3227.15.text:
PRIME MINISTER: Let me just answer, I’ve
been to North Carolina many years ago and

3231.98.text:
I have not yet made it to Mississippi, but

3235.39.text:
The guidance that we put out, the Foreign
Office, gives advice on travel, and it obviously

3240.13.text:
deals with laws in situations as they are,
and it tries to give that advice dispassionately,

3245.72.text: But it's very important that it does so.

3247.98.text:
It's something that a lot of attention is

3251.56.text:
Our view on any of these things is that we
believe that we should be trying to use law

3256.32.text:
to end discrimination rather than to embed
it or enhance it.

3260.26.text:
And that's something we're comfortable saying
to countries and friends anywhere in the world.

3265.82.text:
But obviously, the laws people pass is a matter
of their own legislatures.

3270.05.text:
But we make clear our own views about the
importance of trying to end discrimination,

3276.36.text:
and we've made some important steps forward
in our own country on that front, which we're

3282.00.text: With that, thank you very much.

3283.25.text: PRESIDENT OBAMA: Thank you very much, everybody.
